content.description: Either jump start or stack a pad (if you're short, you may need two) to reach an obvious right angling flake at around 10 feet. Get your feet super high and pull off the ground with difficulty. Make a few powerful and awkward moves to establish yourself on the slab. Use thin crimps and delicate smears to make your way up the slab and gain the top out high off the deck.There is a lower start that adds quality and much difficulty. Atleast a grade or two. Start with a sloping sharp right hand gaston seam and left hand to the left on a more horizontal seam. Campus off the ground a get a foot level with your hands and make a hard move up to the big flake, match with difficulty then continue up. This seems to be the more natural start, but is probably closer to V8 rather than V5.Falling from anywhere on the slab could have some consequences. While the slab isn't completely free of lichen, it is reasonably clean along the line of travel and all of the hand and footholds that you need are clean.If the start wasn't so awkward, this climb might be deserving of three stars. As is, it's still a challenging and engaging line that is worth trying.
content.protection: A few pads are useful since it's tall and you may need to stack some to reach the start.
content.location: Located on The Font Boulder. When walking from The Conditions Boulder, walk around the right side and this is the first problem encountered. It is immediately left of a tree.

content.description: Jump start up to a large feature. Campus out to a big crystal. Find a smear and bust a big deadpoint to a sidepull. Figure out a way to press it out onto the slab.Continue to the top of the boulder with hand smears and palm presses.Shorter folks may need to stack some pads in order to jump up to the rail.
content.protection: Landing is decent but once on the feature, the climber is already a good height off the deck, tossing for the sidepull can spit you off. 2-4 pads
content.location: This problem is on the right side of the downhill face of the boulder. The boulder is steeply overhanging then rounds out into a slab. This problem is next to a large tree.Just around the left side from "Font Problem" and "Blood Sample".

content.description: Stand start with both hands at the lip of the steep overhang.  The right hand is a good crimp sidepull and the left hand is a super slopey series of grains and crystals a few feet to the left. Find a way onto the wall and reach up to bad holds on the slab and figure out how to top it.
content.protection: 2-3 pads. Landing is a slight hill but fairly flat.
content.location: This problem is found between the aesthetic arete and the big bulbous bulge out right.Between "Sick of Life" and "Spectral Revelations". This problem actually uses the left hand starting hold of "Spectral Revelations" as a good sidepull for the starting right hand.

content.description: Squat start the lip of the steep overhang with a slopey meathook for the right hand and a slopey pinch just left of it with a crucial thumbcatch. Find a foot and make a huge lockoff to a far sloper to the right. figure out how to match and then piece together the puzzling mantle.
content.protection: 3 pads. The landing i fairly flat but a bit awkward and the topout is insecure.
content.location: This problem is found on the overhanging side of the boulder that faces the Swirley Boulder and Conditions Boulder. It is found about 10 feet to the right of the arete known as "Sick of Life".

content.description: The full sit to Sick of Life. Sit start with the left hand scoop or the texture below, right hand on the low two/three finger crimp. Fire up to the arete and finish of Sick of Life. Felt like this deserved its own listing. Grade check anyone?

Squat start the arete with a low sloping left-hand dish just above the arete and a round sloping knob/ crystal for the right-hand. This hold is on the lip of the overhang. Pull on and figure out how to move up utilizing some neat holds on the arete and a crystal edge, until you can eventually reach a rail feature. Press out left on to the slab and match the rail before finishing up in easier terrain by either mantling the arete or heading up the slab.This problem has excellent rock quality and hasn't seen any attention in years.The full sit start with the same left-hand dish and a right hand sloping horizontal seam on the overhang bumps the grade up a notch or two.
content.location: From the Conditions Boulder, this is the first problem visible on the large Font Boulder located in the clearing.

content.description: Stand start on two slopers on opposing sides of the overhanging lip. Pull onto the wall and smack up to some slopers and funk your way up to the top of the bulge then continue up the hands-free slab
content.location: This boulder problem is found just right of the arete named "Sick of Life" and on the opposite side of the boulder as "Font Problem".

content.description: The nice scooping slab offers some fun slab climbing with little to no hand holds and good smears.These slabs are great to practice on footwork and balance and would be good for new climbers.There are about two or three variations here, each starting a few feet over. All are about the same grade and hard to distinguish, hence make it all the same climb.Sit starting on the arete, just left of "Sick of Life SDS" is a project. Seems to be possible using a cool undercling feature and possibly a heelhook.
content.location: This aesthetic scooping slab is located just to the left of the obvious arete in the clearing known as "Sick of Life".

content.description: Stand start with a sloping right-hand pinch and a decent left-hand gaston in a diagonal seam. Find a foot to weight and pull off the ground. A few smacks on slopers gains you the top of this boulder.
content.location: On the backside of this large boulder. This problem is located a few feet left of "The Font Problem" and a few feet right of "Blood Sample".

content.description: Desperate slopers up a short bulge that deserves far more traffic than it gets.  Sit start beneath the bulge with a good edge above your head, a good foot, and a divot for your left hand.  Pull up and left to a slopey pinch, adjust your feet, and slap left again into the slopey bowl above.  Make an absolutely desperate match on the nothingness and move left to a sloping crimp that will feel like a jug.  Topout and run to the top of the boulder.
content.location: On the backside of the Font Boulder.  Head past Swirley to the Conditions boulder, then continue towards the large boulder behind Conditions on the right.  This problem is on the uphill side.

content.description: Sit start under the overhang with a large but sloping lefthand gaston and right hand high on a sloping horizontal. Pull up to a crimper, then a nubbin, then figure out a way to the giant sidepull and eventually the top of the sloping boulder.
content.protection: 2-3 pads. Landing is flat but angled.
content.location: The back side of the boulder. Sitting. Just left of "Font Problem".

content.description: Start kneeling under the over hang with a decent edge for the left hand and a larger slightly lower edge/ pinch for the right. Pull on and make a few hard moves up to a nub and a large sidepull with nearly zero feet. Once here, smack up to some crystals and some more Slopers and squeeze your way up some seams to the top of the boulder.Incredibly powerful problem on good textured rock.
content.location: This is the steep overhanging problem 8 feet left of "The Font Problem". The giant sidepull undercling is the telltale sign for the problem.

content.description: Squat start with a right hand pinch with a vertical seam in it and a slopey crystal pinch for the left. This left hand pinch is found on the lower section of the large sidepull used for "Blood Sample". Pull onto the wall with a good foot and smack up to a decent sloping seam. Match it, then smack out to a sloper, then bump to another sloper. Once on the sloper, match the slopers, then continue up to more slopers. Once on the slopers, flip the hand and press the slopers in order to stand on top of the slopers.Good, powerful and slopey.Believe it or not, cold and dry conditions may help for this problem. Slopes!
content.protection: 2 pads. This powerful problem is surprisingly committing for being fairly short.
content.location: This boulder problem is found in between "Blood Sample" and "Font Problem". It is a lower start to "Font Sample".

content.description: The rock quality looks good  but this boulder is in desperate need of some cleaning to make most if not all of the problems climbable. I don't think many people travel out to this one even though it's  about 100 ft past The Conditions Boulder. I don't think the lines on this are as classic as the ones on Conditions. That being said get out there and clean/climb them and let people know.
